Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Integrative Graduate Training In Ocean Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award will train a new generation of scholars to use integrative, cross-disciplinary, and cross-scale approaches to investigate problems of ocean change. Intellectual Merit: Human activities are causing physical and biological changes in the ocean. Some of these changes threaten the persistence of contemporary marine ecosystems and the societies they support. The scale and likely consequences of ocean change are substantial, but ocean change is difficult to observe and invisible to many sectors of society. A key innovation is to frame research questions in a problem-driven, socially-defined context. Trainees will collaborate to explore ocean conditions, biological and ecological responses to changing ocean conditions, their impacts on human institutions and welfare, and opportunities to build resilience in this social-ecological system. The research performed by trainees will enhance our understanding of change in the ocean and its impacts on ecosystems and social institutions.

Broader impacts of the program arise from the coupled-systems approach. Trainees will emerge prepared to address problems of ocean change from a coupled social-ecological perspective, communicate with diverse groups, establish credibility inside and outside academics, and fairly represent uncertainties inherent in the study of ocean change. In so doing, they will serve societal needs and help to transform the way society views the ocean and the changes induced by human activity. We will seek to broaden participation from underrepresented minorities, especially those from coastal tribes, Alaska natives, and Pacific Islanders, and in so doing, we will serve communities and cultures likely to be among the first affected by ocean change.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We trained 30 graduate students at the University of Washington in interdisciplinary thinking related to changing ocean conditions. We began from the premise that rapid change in ocean conditions—including changes in fisheries, food production, and sea level—will create ecological, socio-economic, and cultural challenges in coming decades. We sought to train students to address these challenges through research designed and performed in collaboration with peers. Trainees worked in small cohorts to advance research of their own design. Their research products have been published in peer-reviewed journals, presented as white-papers to state agencies, and adopted as new curricula in K-8 classrooms.

 

The intellectual merits of the trainees’ work are best reflected in scholarly outputs that serve both science and society. These include consideration of 1) scale-dependence and limits to inference in ocean change research; 2) social vulnerability to climate-associated fisheries closures; 3) creation of a community knowledge network for Pacific Islanders exposed to climate variability; 4) local adaptation to sea level rise; 5) assessment of blue carbon potential in Puget Sound, WA; and 6) translating climate science for use at regional scales.

 

The broader impacts of this project are reflected in internal and external benefits. Internally, trainees learned to work with peers from diverse disciplines across the university—for example, trainees from atmospheric science, quantitative science, oceanography, and public affairs jointly worked on a project concerning local government responses to sea level rise. In another example, trainees from chemical oceanography, biological oceanography, fisheries, biology, and atmospheric science created a local learning network in Pohnpei, Micronesia. This cross-disciplinary collaboration and peer-to-peer learning expanded the horizons of each trainee, increasing their employability and offering downstream benefits to an educated and productive workforce.

 

External benefits accrued to the larger community. For four consecutive years, trainees hosted a public seminar series featuring eminent speakers from around the U.S. and abroad. On a weekly basis, speakers addressed themes as varied as ecological change in coral reef systems, changes in fisheries and food production, the roles of government and NGOs in response to rapid ocean change, and social and ethical responsibilities associated with the changing ocean. These seminars were attended by up to 250 students and faculty from across campus and from the community at large and served the interests of a broad range of participants.

 

Other benefits accrued to specific stakeholders. Trainees worked with coastal tribes, Pacific islanders, shellfish growers, fisheries managers, state agency personnel, and K-8 students and teachers to co-produce knowledge relevant to each group. Among the outcomes of these collaborations are improved prospects for mussel aquaculture in Puget Sound, new guidance for marine resource managers, improved understanding of the socio-economic and cultural challenges associated with changing ocean conditions, and new K-8 curricula and associated skills among K-8 students.
